p: Beyond heterogeneous urban environments, the traditional dichotomy between “rural” and “urban” inadequately represents the diversity of relationships between people and the landscapes that strongly affect vulnerability (Lerner & Eakin, 2011). In areas of high population density, even if most people are affected similarly by exposure to a given local climate impact, various activity spaces—defined as, “a geographic extent in which people move in the course of their daily activities” (Ren, 2016; see also Kwan, 2013; Kwan & Schwanen, 2016)—will be affected differently. These discrepancies were clearly revealed by the effects of the Maharashtra Floods of 2005 in Mumbai, India and Hurricane Sandy, for example (Chatterjee, 2010; Schmeltz et al., 2013).
